items.message: High river levels today and overnight may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 30 and 31 January 2026. This information is correct as of 3:00pm on Friday 30 January 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 18cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has areas with some water on the road. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse. This is a Flood Alert Update. River levels are falling steadily, but continue to remain high at the Stinsford river gauge as a result of the recent rainfall. Flooding could still affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham, with low lying land and roads near rivers expected to be most affected. Further rain is expected tonight and tomorrow. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. People in this area should continue to monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The Powdermill Stream in Crowhurst had fallen near to normal following Tuesday's rain. In Bulverhythe river levels remain higher than normal, and minor flooding will continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground. Friday morning's rain is causing river levels to rise. Further, small, amounts of rain are forecast Friday afternoon, and Saturday afternoon. River levels will likely rise a relatively small amount. Should not rise as high as recent events, but minor flood impacts, with water approaching gardens in both Crowhurst and Bulverhythe could be possible on Saturday. River levels in Crowhurst should return near to normal on Sunday. In Bulverhythe river levels could remain higher than normal all weekend. More rain is forecast Monday afternoon, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible next week. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Crowhurst. This message will be updated by 14:00 31/01/2026.

The lower River Parrett remains bank-full and spillways are running. Further rain is forecast throughout Friday and Saturday. Rainfall will mainly be light but there is the potential for periods of heavier downpours and blustery conditions. We are closely monitoring the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. items.message: The river level at Huish Episcopi is currently 8.80m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi is 8.55m and stable. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once river spillways stop running. Further rain is forecast throughout Friday and Saturday. Rainfall will mainly be light but there is the potential for periods of heavier downpours and blustery conditions. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 31/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers had fallen near to normal following Tuesday's rain. However, Friday morning's rain is cause rivers to rise again. Small amounts of rain are forecast Friday afternoon and Saturday afternoon. River levels will likely rise through much of Friday and Saturday, although there will be periods when rivers stabilise, or fall. River levels are not expected to rise as high as recent events. Only minor flood impacts are expected, to affect fields, roads, and gardens. River levels should finally begin to fall Sunday. However, more rain is forecast Monday, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible next week. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood (Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly, and North Street Alfriston). This message will be updated by 14:00 31/01/2026.

The Western Rother is high at Fittleworth, and higher than normal at Lodsbridge near Selham. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect Fittleworth Mill and nearby properties. Rain Friday morning is causing river levels to rise. Further rain is forecast Friday afternoon and Saturday afternoon, although relatively small amounts. Small river rises are expected, and in most communities should not rise as high as recent events. Only minor flood impacts are expected to affect fields, roads, and gardens. Including gardens of isolated mill properties at Lodsbridge near Selham. In Fittleworth, the river might again rise close to recent peaks and affect Fittleworth Mill. Near Liss, river levels will initially peak early Saturday morning, but will not finally peak until early Sunday morning. Near Fittleworth, river levels are unlikely to peak until late Sunday.  However more rain is forecast Monday, which will cause the river to rise again. Keep in place any flood protection products you may have. Including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. This message will be updated by 14:00 31/01/2026.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.70m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.72m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and additional pumps are operational at Northmoor. Further rain is forecast throughout Friday and Saturday. High tide at Southampton is forecast at 21:15 and 22:30 30/01/2026 at 4.75 metres Chart Datum (2.01 mAOD). For 1.5 hours either side of high water, the incoming tide will prevent river from flowing to sea. This may flood the access road and the car park near to the White Swan Pub at Mansbridge. Levels are steady but still remain high at the Stinsford river gauge following prolonged rainfall and high groundwater. Further rain is expected tonight and tomorrow. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.72m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.74m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 remains closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. 

For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. 

Showers are forecast tonight and on Saturday. Rainfall will mainly be light but there is potential for heavier downpours. Sunday and Monday are both forecast to be drier until more rain arrives later on Monday.

We are monitoring the situation closely and checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 31/01/2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Lox had fallen significantly following Tuesday's rain. However, rain Friday morning will cause the River Lox to rise again. Minor flood impacts could affect fields, roads, and gardens near the top of the River Lox, including isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. From 16:00 30/01/2026 minor flood impacts could also affect fields, roads and gardens near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Further rain is forecast Friday afternoon and Saturday afternoon, although relatively small amounts. Additional, small, river rises are expected. Should not rise as high as recent events. River levels will not finally peak until late Sunday. However more rain is forecast Monday, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible next week. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst. This message will be updated by 14:00 31/01/2026.

Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk . 
This message will be updated by 11:41AM on 31 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.72m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.74m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 remains closed. For road closure information please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/ 

We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. The River Tone level is still too high for pumping at Currymoor. We will commence pumping here once river levels allow. 

Showers are forecast tonight and on Saturday. Rainfall will mainly be light but there is potential for heavier downpours. Sunday and Monday are both forecast to be drier until more rain arrives later on Monday.

items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible , as a lot of rain has fallen this week (41mm). 
Flooding is affecting the electricity sub station in Rectory Lane, Meonstoke. The Winterbourne will be flowing across Rectory Lane and behind the Buck's Head Pub. On Friday 30/01/2026 and Saturday 31/01/2026, up to 15mm of rain is forecast on each day. Sunday 01/02/2026 and Monday 02/02/2026, are expected to be drier. If heavy rain affects the Meon Valley in the coming days then groundwater levels at the borehole in Meonstoke will rise into next week. If not, then levels may peak over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed .

items.message:
The River Yeo level remains high and the drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.57m and stable. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.30m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road about 8.8m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once spillways stop running. 
Showers are forecast tonight and on Saturday. Rainfall will mainly be light but there is potential for heavier downpours. Sunday and Monday are both forecast to be drier until more rain arrives later on Monday.
We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1 PM on 31/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message:
Water levels remain high and continued flooding is expected on Friday evening and on Saturday, 31/01/2026. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around Moorland including Horlake, Saltmoor, Fordgate and Chadmead. 

Levels in the River Tone and on Currymoor are stable although still very high. The River Tone is still too high for pumping at Currymoor station. Athelney spillway is still running into Saltmoor and Northmoor. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. 

Showers are forecast for Friday night and on Saturday. Rainfall will mainly be light but there is potential for heavier downpours. Sunday and Monday are both forecast to be drier until more rain arrives later on Monday. Rivers remain extremely responsive to further rain.

Act on your flood plan if you have one. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1PM on 31 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 30/01/2026, after above average rainfall in January. 
Minor flood impacts could affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. A small amount of water may appear on Denton Road. Groundwater at Houndean Bottom borehole is expected to stop rising around the 31/01/2026. However, small amounts of rain are forecast Friday and Saturday, with the suggestion of more rain next week. Further groundwater rise could be possible next week, which may cause water to flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. If rain continues, flood impacts may remain until mid February. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , including rainfall, groundwater and forecasts. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 02 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Flooding is expected from 29 January 2026. 
Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase are rising. Areas that could be affected include: Lower Allen Vale including New Town, Witchampton. The groundwater level at Woodyates borehole has risen to 106.82m, and is expected to rise further into next week. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 3:30PM on 04 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 01/02/2026 due to a wet January 2026. 
In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at Kings Somborne has risen by 14cm. Flooding could affect cellars in a small number of properties along Winchester Road, in central King's Somborne and in Little Somborne from Sunday 01/02/2026. However, the groundwater level may peak before these impacts occur. Small amounts of rain are forecast from today (30/01/2026) to Monday (02/02/2026). If heavy rain affects Kings Somborne and Little Somborne, groundwater levels will continue rising well into next week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.
